narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about primate intelligence and writing skills.

This course provided a comprehensive overview of the cognitive capacities in primates and humans and their evolutionary trajectory, through a perfect blend of primatology, comparative psychology, anthropology, and evolutionary biology. More importantly, it helped hone the all-important skillset to read, assimilate and analyze multiple, often-conflicting, technical research papers in the field. This course has definitely equipped me with a better scientific mindset, as well as a more nuanced understanding of what makes humans special in comparison to their closest relatives.

I learned about primates and how similar to and distinct they are from humans. I gained knowledge about primates that I had not previously known, such as information about theory of mind and mental maps.
Different aspects of primate intelligence

I've learned a lot about big ape cognition, especially about topics such as theory of mind, theories about the evolution of primate intelligence, specific social cognitive abilities, and their social organization
Heightened understanding of primate intelligence (both human and non-human), evolutionary theory and related concepts, theory of mind and related concepts, the roots of language, culture, etc.
How to thunk and read about questions of primate and other non-human intelligence

The class is essentially a survey of primate intelligence. There are some topics on humans and other animals as well, so it includes intelligence in general. The topics are a lot of "these primates can do this and these cannot, here are the studies that show us this".
Skills in reading technical papers and thinking critically about them.
Understanding of evolutionary history of primates especially as pertaining to cognition

This was my first Anthropology course and it helped shape how I look at human biology in a meaningful way. Not only this, but the discussion section helped develop my writing abilities for a more scientifically, argumentative approach.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Excellent course and learnt a lot of interesting things

Strengths: 1. the course covers an expertly-chosen combination of material in comparative psychology and primatology/anthropology that is consistently relevant and intriguing; 2. Prof Watts is one of the most knowledgeable academics in this field, and will always eagerly dish out detailed answers to any possible question you might have; 3. the readings, albeit long, were very relevant to the lectures and helped a lot, although they weren't necessary to succeed in the course if one didn't have time to do them. Weaknesses: nothing really comes to mind, this was a great course.
The use of examples and videos was very engaging. The assignments were manageable, though the readings were not as engaging.

The course is extremely well-structured, with a detailed syllabus covering a variety of topics.  The assignments are also very interesting and help with understanding course material: three short papers (reading critiques), one response to a famous documentary film, and a term paper.  The papers are very flexible and are designed in such a way that students are able to select topics of their interest.

Strengths: if you actually attend lecture and follow it, the topics are really interesting, and Professor Watts is really enthusiastic about what he teaches.
Weaknesses: lectures can be a bit dry sometimes, and the PowerPoint presentations can be improved

Strengths: the course content itself was interesting, the reading critiques and video essay assignments were often fun to write, and the instructor was clearly extremely educated in his field. He was often able to offer relevant anecdotes from his own fieldwork and research experiences to answer questions from students.

Weaknesses: the readings could be a bit excessive.
Incredible course, lecture could be more discussion oriented

It was a quite interesting class, especially since Dr. Watts is such an interesting lecturer and shares his own videos and stories. However, the papers are the only assignments and sometimes they can feel a bit disconnected from the lectures. This can be nice or bad, depending on your style. I would say, though, that more feedback on why we got the grades we did could be useful.
A strength was the amount of videos shown in class to contextualize the lectures and readings.  I think more targeted feedback on writing assignments would have been helpful.
More discussion post opportunities considering their weight in class grading scheme
The course was engaging and Professor Watt's passion for the subject shined through each lecture. The class fostered a very free and open environment for discussion.

Great writing credit option as a stem major, interesting material, kind professor, open ended paper topics that allow you to write about what interested you the most. Definitely would have been better in person though, Professor Watts's lecture style is somewhat dry over zoom and class engagement was very low.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course material was generally well-adapted to the virtual environment, although some of the videos shown in class could have been provided as prior 'reading' to help get through the material quicker. The in-person office hours in the latter half of the semester were great, since most courses have lacked any kind of in-person component this semester.
I appreciated the recorded lectures. Our professor was flexible with deadlines.
We had synchronous Zoom lectures, which were also recorded and accessible through Canvas.  We also occasionally had breakout rooms during the live class to discuss topics with fellow students.
There was a lot of use of videos in lecture that was helpful.
Brief discussion of readings during class could be helpful. I appreciated the professors willingness to schedule office hours.
Great integration of readings and asynchronous work into live lectures
I thought the course was conducted well despite COVID restrictions
The class was a live online lecture that fit well with Watt's PowerPoints. The recorded lectures also made the class open for anyone regardless of time restrictions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes if interested about how other animals use cognitive skills
Yes good writing credit.

If you have any interest in comparative psychology and/or primatology, take it. If you're curious about how our cognitive abilities came to be, take it. If you want to know whether and how humans are different from other primates, take it. There's a lot to learn, and not much any work (four short papers and a term paper); it's also an easy A if you're interested in the material. Also, it's only the easiest WR credit you'll find (no extra work, only a drab hour-long section every week). Need I say more?
I would recommend, info about primates is always interesting to me.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! As someone who had never taken a course in anthropology before, it was an extremely valuable addition to my Yale education to take a course with a leading expert in primatology!  The course is very well-structured with lots of feedback, and lectures are engaging and interesting!
Absolutely-an interesting course!

I found this course quite interesting even though I did not have very much prior knowledge about any of the topics being discussed. I would recommend it for anyone who is interested in learning about primates, the ways in which they are similar and different from us, and the ethics of researching them. It is a WR, so there are quite a few papers (4 and a final paper), but the papers were each individually not that difficult.
Yes. It was a great class, and I learned a lot!
Yes

I'd recommend this course to any student genuinely interested in the evolution of primate intelligence. Otherwise, one may find themselves struggling to stay engaged with lectures and getting through readings.
Yes. Brilliantly designed course and very thought-provoking.
If you're interested in the topics, then yes. Dr. Watts is pretty interesting and the course is not very demanding at all. It is also a good WR credit if you need one.
Yes, if they are interested in evolution or cognition.
Yes. The course compelled me to reconsider many aspects of human cognition and exactly how unique it really is.
Yes, the course was fun and interesting to follow along. The grading was geared towards helping you grow and learn to produce better arguments.
